name: The Bowery Boys Podcast
bio: This is the Instagram account of The Bowery Boys: New York City History podcast.

social_posts.post_text:
Thank you Nicki Greenberg for sending us a copy of your new book The Detective’s Guide to New York City! We are thrilled we helped inspire such a cool, entertaining book. A great gift for a young teen reader into mystery and history.

#sardis #boweryboys #mysterynovels #newyorkcity #nyc

Our 400th episode comes out this Friday. Here are five somewhat hard clues to the subject of that show. Can you guess the historic figure? Five more clues on the way — and you’ll love the show when it comes out on Friday.

#boweryboys #podcastsofinstagram

The Brutalist apartment buildings Chatham Towers.

#brutalism #brutalistarchitecture #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #chinatownnyc #architecture #architecturephotography

The 400th episode of the Bowery Boys podcast looks at the life of Jacob Riis, the pioneering journalist and reformer. 

No area of Manhattan is associated more with Riis than Columbus Park, the former site of Mulberry Bend in the old Five Points neighborhood.

It is through his efforts that the tenements of the Bend were demolished and replaced with this park (originally called Mulberry Bend Park) which opened 125 years ago.

For more information listen to our show.

#boweryboys #columbuspark #chinatown #chinatownnyc #jacobriis

Quiet evening in Red Hook, the Manhattan skyline in the distance.

#redhookbrooklyn #boweryboys #brooklyn

More Red Hook holiday wanderings on an interesting evening. 

#boweryboys #redhookbrooklyn #christmas #christmasdecor #brooklyn
Over a 100 firefighters on the scene at the massive fire located at the car impound in Erie Basin.

One of New York City's most unique holiday celebrations takes place this Sunday (Dec 18) at 3pm at The Church of The Intercession in Upper Manhattan.

Since 1911 a special reading of ‘Twas the Night Before Christmas has been followed by a candlelit procession to the gravesite of the poem’s author Clement Clarke Moore in Trinity’s uptown cemetery.

Frequently a person dressed as Saint Nicholas (the saint, not the Santa) leads the procession. In recent decades, a person of some renown reads the poem such as in 2003 when basketball great Isiah Thomas brought Moore’s words to life.

Pictured here: In 1990, Joyce Dinkins, wife of the mayor David Dinkins, reads the poem to local kids.

Visit our website (or of course that of the Church of the Intercrssion) for more details.

#newyorkcity #christmas #christmasinnewyork #christmastradition
Christmas in the Meatpacking District. Lights designed to enhance the historic stone streets. Bonus points because I’m here while it’s rainy.

Have you heard our interview with ‘puzzle king’ AJ Jacobs, author of The Puzzler: One Man's Quest to Solve the Most Baffling Puzzles Ever, from Crosswords to Jigsaws to the Meaning of Life?

AJ leads us through a maze of interesting stories about the world’s most popular puzzles — many with a connection to New York City.

Listen today on your favorite podcast player!

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast  #thepuzzler #puzzles #crossword #wordle

Cultural historian and tour guide Kyle Supley joins Greg Young on this week’s episode of the Bowery Boys podcast on a nostalgic journey to New York’s two 20th century World’s Fairs at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

Listen to Treasures from the World’s Fair today on your favorite podcast player.

#worldsfair1964 #worldsfair1939 #newyorkcity #flushingmeadows #boweryboyspodcast #boweryboys #boweryboysnyc #cityreliquary

Kyle Supley and his fabulous World’s Fair memorabilia collection at the City Reliquary. 
Have you heard the latest Bowery Boys podcast? Many of these items are featured on the show including the wacky light-up necklace and the ‘chicken coop door’.

What special mementos from historic events past do you have lying around your home?

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #worldsfair #cityreliquary #collectibles #souvenirs #discoshirt

Had to wrap up this week’s journey to the World’s Fair with an actual trip to Flushing Meadows Corona Park and the Queens Museum to check out their World’s Fair collectibles (near the Panorama).

Listen to this week’s episode featuring Kyle Supley for more on World’s Fair history.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #flushingmeadows #worldsfair

More images from the City Reliquary. There’s a fantastic exhibition on Wonder Woman presently on view. And the museum is perhaps best known for its spectacular Statue of Liberty collection. Pay them a visit some weekend!

#cityreliquary #statueofliberty🗽 #museumsofinstagram #brooklyn #wonderwoman

In honor of Julius’ Bar in the West Village becoming New York’s newest official landmark, we are replaying our show on the Sip-In of 1966, a small but significant protest at the bar which set the stage for future advances in LGBTQ life.

On that show we also interviewed Hugh Ryan about his then new book When Brooklyn Was Queer, recorded at Julius. Since this show originally ran in 2019, Ryan has since released a new book The Women’s House of Detention (which we also featured on a recent show).

A toast to the city’s newest landmark! Listen today on your favorite podcast player.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #juliusbar #lgbtq🌈

Tin Building at the Fulton Fish Market, 1951

Tin Building at the South Street Seaport, 2022

#tinbuilding #southstreetseaport

The new episode of the Bowery Boys podcast revisits the South Street Seaport and the legacy of the Fulton Fish Market. If you haven’t been down to the Seaport recently, it’s made quite an interesting transformation in recent years. 

And even with the continued threat of new development, reminders of its past can still be found everywhere. 

Listen to our new episode today!

#southstreetseaport #southstreetseaportmuseum #fultonfishmarket #newyorkcity #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

Views from inside the Tin Building, the lux food hall within a redesigned vestige of the old Fulton Fish Market’s tin building. You should definitely check out the reference to the market’s past including a wall of photographs by Barbara Mensch.

#tinbuilding #southstreetseaport #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast
The Ansonia, looking absolutely beautiful tonight.

See what these pots say? Corlears Hook! They were made over 200 years ago by Thomas W. Commeraw, a free black potter working in New York in the years following the Revolutionary War.

They’re featured in the New-York Historical Society’s new show Crafting Freedom: The Life and Legacy of Free Black Potter Thomas W. Commeraw. 

This show is about so much more than pottery! It’s a fascinating glimpse into the lives of free blacks at a time when slavery was still legal in the state of New York. Great interactive map of early 19th century New York as well.

The show opened today and runs through the end of May.

#nyhs #newyorkhistoricalsociety #blackhistory #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

In the new art-filled episode of the Bowery Boys podcast, Tom and Greg look at Hopper’s life, influence and specific fascination with the city, inspired by the recent show Edward Hopper’s New York at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

Hopper captured New York architecture in a fascinating way, always distorting or twisting details to enhance the mood. Once you see a few dozen Hopper paintings, you’ll be seeing his perspective everywhere.

Here are three paintings discussed on this week’s show with places that may have inspired Hopper’s work. 

Listen to the show today on your favorite podcast player.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #edwardhopper #artoftheday
null

Edward Hopper’s long time home and studio at 3 Washington Square North is one of the Village’s great artistic landmarks. 

And it’s still around! Greg paid a visit to the studio in 2019 for Open House New York. Hopefully it will be open again to the public soon.

Listen to our newest podcast on the story of Edward Hopper and his New York paintings.

#edwardhopper #washingtonsquarepark #greenwichvillage #boweryboys

On this week’s new episode of the Bowery Boys podcast, Tom visits the Edward Hopper House and Museum in Nyack, where the painter lived into his early 20s.

The charming town of Nyack also preserves the historic buildings that Hopper grew up around, structures that heavily influenced his painterly interests.

The exhibit also features a most unusual artifact — Edward Hopper’s bicycle!

We highly recommend spending an afternoon in Nyack and paying a visit to the house and to the Edward Jo’s gravesite. And for those who heard our Ghost Stories of the Hudson River last year, you know the town also contains a very different type of historic attraction 👻

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #edwardhopper #edwardhopperhouse #nyack #nyackny
The Anish Kapoor sculpture, similar to his Chicago ‘bean’, is finally completed at 56 Leonard Street. What do you think?

You see hundreds of portraits and selfies scrolling through Instagram. Now gaze upon  one of the very first.

In this week’s episode, learn all about Dorothy Catherine Draper, a truly forgotten figure in American history. She was the first woman to ever sit for a photograph — a daguerrotype, actually, in the year 1840, upon the rooftop of the school which would become New York University.

This wasn’t a casual photo shoot; it was a scientific experiment. The photo was taken by her brother John William Draper, an instructor at the university who was experimenting with photography processes alongside Samuel Morse. 

Discover her fascinating story in this week’s episode. Listen today on your favorite podcast player. 

Pictured: Draper in 1840 and later in 1893.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #photography #photographyhistory
Nothing like a diner on the Upper East Side on a clear evening.

social_posts.post_text:
Thanks to Patrick Bringley for joining us on this week’s episode to chat about his new book All The Beauty In the World: The Metropolitan Museum and Me. Bringley is a former guard at the museum and in our show, he reveals the fascinating interworkings at New York’s largest museum.

Listen today on your favorite podcast player!

#metropolitanmuseum #metropolitanmuseumofart #newyorkcity #boweryboys #newbookstagram

social_posts.post_text:
Just had to visit the spot where the Mona Lisa was exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art sixty years ago this month. And of course some other favorite spots, including some mentioned in this week’s show with special guest Patrick Bringley.

Our new episode Mona Lisa at the Metropolitan Museum is now available. Listen today!

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #metropolitanmuseumofart #monalisa

I took a weekend trip to Baltimore to do research for a side history project Im working on. So many interesting places to visit! Among my stops:

1) Baltimore harbor 
2) Mount Vernon 
3) Peabody Library
4-5) Maryland Center of History and Culture
6-7) Walters Museum of Art
8) Papermoon Diner
9)Charles Carroll house on Johns Hopkins campus
10) And the charming neighborhood of Hampden

Any New York fans of Baltimore? Any favorite places? I know, I didn’t get to the Visionary Art Museum. Next time!

-Greg

#baltimore #boweryboys
It's coming... Metropolis to Gotham an NYC Comic history! Welcome Greg from @boweryboysnyc to our chat! 2-4pm today! @makerparkradio

In the new Bowery Boys episode, we ask the questions — how did Wall Street get its name? And how did the street become synonymous with the entire American financial system?

One of the first facts you learn as a student of New York City history is that Wall Street is named for an actual wall that once stretched along this very spot during the days of the Dutch when New York was known as New Amsterdam.

The particulars of the story, however, are far more intriguing. Because the Dutch called the street alongside the wall something very different.

During the colonial era, the wall was torn down and turned into the center of New York life, complete with Trinity Church, City Hall and a shoreline market with a disturbing connection to one New York’s financial livelihoods — slavery.

So how did this street become so associated with American finance? The story involves Alexander Hamilton, a busy coffee house and a very important tree.

Listen today on your favorite podcast player!

#boweryboys #wallstreet #nyse #newyorkstockexchange #federalhall #newamsterdam #slavery #colonialnewyork #nychistory

Did you know you can walk along the site of the old wall (or palisade) of Wall Street? Just look down!

A marker on the street in front of Federal Hall indicates where to look. You can find square wooden markers emanating out from there. Although they are in poor condition today, a few are visible enough to allow your imagination to fill in the rest. These reminders of New Amsterdam were placed here in 2009.

The illustrations here, from two old history books, are not exactly accurate but they give you a good sense of the general proportions of the original palisade here.

Listen to our latest podcast for more information on the old wall of Wall Street.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #wallstreet #newamsterdam

A marker for the 1711 slave market sits in a small park at Wall and Water Streets, just west of the present shoreline. Enslaved people were both sold and ‘lent out’ at this market.

During the colonial era, New York had the largest population of enslaved people north of Maryland. Although the market would cease operations by the 1760s, slavery would be a presence on the streets of New York until it was at last abolished in 1827.

To get a fuller sense of the story of slavery in New York, head several blocks north from Wall Street to the African Burial Ground museum at Broadway and Duane Streets. 

And find more details on life in Colonial New York in our latest podcast on the history of Wall Street.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #wallstreet #africanburialground #slavery #colonialamerica

It can be kind of difficult to appreciate the architecture of Wall Street because the street is narrow and the buildings so tall. 

But head to the corner of Wall and Pearl Streets for some truly remarkable detailing on some early 20th century buildings: the Munson Steamship headquarters (67 Wall Street) and the Seaman’s Bank for Savings (74 Wall Street) with its curious nautical themed carvings.

But my favorite is the mythology themed medallions at 63 Wall Street, built in 1929.

For a look back at some older Wall Street history, check out our new podcast How Wall Street Got Its Name.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #wallstreet #architecture #architecturephotography

The unique lobby of 60 Wall Street presents an interesting question — should the whimsical 1989 design by Kevin Roche be protected to save it from a destructive renovation?

Check out Christopher Bonanos Sept ‘22 article for New York Magazine regarding an unconventional drive to save this ‘weird and ridiculous’ lobby which has its share of supporters and nostalgists.

After all there are very few places in New York (outside a botanic garden) where New Yorkers can hang out with palm trees.

And there’s something about that subway entrance that I’ve always found quite lovely.

#wallstreet #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #60wallstreet #lobbiesofnewyork #architecture

Red Hook on a windy sunset.

#redhookbrooklyn #sunsetlovers #brooklyn #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

The Buttonwood Agreement is the pact signed by 24 stockbrokers which created what became the New York Stock Exchange. 

It was indeed signed under an actual buttonwood (or American sycamore) tree. The tree once stood near the corner of Wall and Pearl, a few blocks east of the present NYSE.

But a new buttonwood tree sits in front of the present stock exchange building, a symbolic tie to 1792.

More information on this week’s podcast.

#wallstreet #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #nyse #buttonwoodagreement

Technically, Wall Street ends at Broadway, upon the doorstep of historic Trinity Church. But a tiny bridge behind the church, hovering over Trinity Place is a spiritual (both literally and figuratively) extension.

The bridge was built in 1989 to connect the church and the former parish house, which was demolished in 2016. It now connects to the sleek new Trinity Commons, a community center with brown hues which mirror the church.

But isn’t the bridge much older? Its design was inspired by the 1866 cast-iron pedestrian bridge which once stood over Broadway at Fulton Street. It was a beauty and captured in some early photography of New York City. It was torn down in 1868. Could you imagine if it were still there today?

More information on the bridge on our website. And more details about Wall Street on our new podcast.

#boweryboys #broadway #trinitychurch #bridgesofinstagram #newyorkcity

With the Scream horror franchise heading to New York City this week in Scream VI, Greg presents his ten favorite scary movies set in the city. From ancient serpents overhead to glamorous vampires and cat people in the alleyways. What are your favorites? 

Visit the website to check out the entire list.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #scream6 #scream #newyorkcity #rosemarysbaby #thehunger

An afternoon stroll through the Irish Hunger Memorial in Battery Park City, which opened to the public in 2002.

#irish #stpatricksday #batteryparkcity

Images from this year’s Mermaid Parade. Perfect weather for a little marine masquerade!
 
#boweryboys #mermaidparade #coneyisland

Perfect weather for a aquatic themed parade, don’t you think?

#mermaidparade #mermaidparade2023 #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #coneyisland #coneyislandboardwalk #coneyislandmermaidparade #brooklyn #nyc #newyorkcity

The Bowery Boys podcast turns sixteen years old today. It can officially get its drivers license!

Head over to the website right now and see a list of all our podcasts — over 400 episodes — in chronological order by subject. From the Lenape to Little Caribbean. From Henry Hudson to Marilyn Monroe.

Thanks for being a listener! Onto another year of shows.

— Greg and Tom

#podcasts #podcasting #nyc #newyorkcity #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

The new Bowery Boys podcast looks at the history of a persistent and vexing problem — street parking. 

In a city with skyrocketing real estate values, why are most city streets still devoted to free car storage? It’s a situation we’re all so used to that we don’t think twice about it. Whatever happened to the curb?

We’re joined in this episode by Slate writer Henry Grabar, author of the new book Paved Paradise: How Parking Explains The World.

Enjoy these images of parking situations throughout New York City history including:
— Harlem, 125th Street, 1949 
— Washington Square North 1937
— Washington Square Park 1960s
— Jones Beach 1934
— Manhattan parking garage 1950s
— Midtown East 1970s

Visit our website for more images and photo credits.

#newyorkcity #nyc #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #parking #parkinggarage #parkinggaragephotography #automobiles #classicauto #classiccars #classiccarsdaily

In 1882, Oscar Wilde took a break from his lecture tour of North America to meet his childhood idol, the aging poet Walt Whitman, who lived in Camden, New Jersey.

Their afternoon together is the stuff of literary legend. Wilde later recounted, “The kiss of Walt Whitman is still on my lips.”

On these special two episodes of The Gilded Gentleman, host Carl Raymond and guests take a look at the lives of Whitman and Wilde, two revolutionary writers, the times in which they lived, their surprising meeting, and how New York inspired them to move onto great fame and celebrity.

Listen today on the Gilded Gentleman podcast, available wherever you get your podcast.

#oscarwilde #waltwhitman #nyc #literaryhistory #gayhistory #lgbthistory #camdennj

Taking in the hazy, Canadian-smoke-filled views of Brooklyn, via the heights of 1 Willoughby Place in downtown Brooklyn. The Williamsburg Savings Bank Tower has some company. 

Thanks to Joe Pikiewicz for giving me a tour on this very unusual day of skyline viewing!

#brooklyn #downtownbrooklyn #skyscrapers

#nathanshotdogeatingcontest #coneyisland

Wanna see what it looks like when a nationally televised event gets rained out? Just a stunning display of nature in Coney Island, right as the men’s portion of the Nathan’s Hot Dog Eating Contest was about to start.

#nathanshotdogs #nathanshotdogeatingcontest #coneyisland #brooklyn

We are so divided as a nation that even the black and white cookie has decided to separate.

#blackandwhitecookies #delisofinstagram #cookies #nyc

On a little road trip through the South and had an excellent day of historical landmark hunting in Charleston, South Carolina. Have you been here before? It’s palm trees, colonial architecture, vintage 20th century shop signs and of course raging heat. In honor of our latest release I may head over to Fort Sumter later….

#charlestonsc #charleston #roadtrip #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

Last evening’s sunset over the harbor, with special guests Lady Liberty and SI Ferry.

#sunsets #newyorkcity

160 years ago today, thousands of people took to the streets of New York in violent protest, fueled by anger over a draft lottery which sent New Yorkers to the front lines of the Civil War. (At least, those who couldn’t afford to pay the $300 fee.)

The mob soon attacked those who supported the draft (Lincoln supporting Republicans) but saved the greatest terror for Black New Yorkers. 160 years ago this very afternoon, a violent group burned down the orphanage for African-American children at Fifth Avenue and 43rd Street.

For more information on the Draft Riots and how it unfolded over the next week, check out our latest podcast which recounts the events through until the end.

#draftriots #draftriots1863 #draftriotsnyc #newyorkcity #forgottenhistory #civilwar #civilwarhistory

Gowanus 2023. Third Street Bridge. 

#gowanus #gowanuscanal #gowanusbrooklyn #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #brooklyn

Don’t mind me, just having a classic bagel and lox sandwich from Russ and Daughters at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #russanddaughters #brooklynnavyyard #bagel #bagelsandwich #brooklyn #goodeats

Surprising sights in Times Square. 

#timessquare #nakedcowboynyc #strike #nyc

For a moment there was only the sound of birds and it was lovely.

#centralpark #upperwestside

The Brooklyn Navy Yard history mural along the wall separating the former site of the yard from Navy Street. Actually I think you would find a lot of impounded cars on the other side of this wall.

#boweryboys #brooklynnavyyard #vinegarhill #muralsofinstagram

This week’s new episode of the Bowery Boys explores the history of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. But you can’t tell the whole story without Vinegar Hill, today a small historic district tucked between the Navy Yard and Dumbo. 

Vinegar Hill (called Irishtown in the mid and late 19th century) is as old as the Yard itself and once contained a haunting link to the Revolutionary War.

Hey and you can get a great brunch there today! Although some of you may have less rosier tales about the place from two or three decades before.

More information on our website. Listen to the episode today.

#vinegarhill #brooklynnavyyard #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #brooklynhistory

One of the most peaceful places in all of New York City — the Naval Cemetery Landscape, a home to pollinating bees, native birds and a host of native plant species. This was once the Brooklyn Navy Yard’s hospital cemetery.

Listen to the story of the Brooklyn Navy Yard in our latest podcast.

#brooklynnavyyard #navalcemeterylandscape #brooklynhistory #boweryboyspodcast #boardwalk #flowerstagram

Although this week’s new podcast is all about the Brooklyn Navy Yard and Vinegar Hill, it dips into the story of Fort Greene as well, thanks to the Prison Ship Martyrs Monument.

The crypt, which contains the remains of those who died on Revolutionary War prison ships, is the second home for these remains. The original crypt sat in Vinegar Hill, created by the shipbuilder whose private shipyard became the basis for the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

Listen to the show today for more information. 

#boweryboyspodcast #forthreene #fortgreenepark #vinegarhill #brooklynnavyyard

Inside the new Jay-Z exhibition at the Brooklyn Public Library’s Central Library at Grand Army Plaza. It was so enjoyable that I almost forgot I was there to check out books.

#jayz #brooklyn #brooklynpubliclibrary

A few views from Summer Streets 2023. Did you take part in any activities today?

#summerstreets #nyc #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

In this week’s new Bowery Boys episode, join Greg as he strolls the romantic, rambling paths of historic Central Park, turning back the clock to the 1860s and 70s, a time of children ice skating on The Lake, carriage rides through The Mall, and bewildering excursions through The Ramble.

Visit some of the most beloved attractions of the park including Bethesda Terrace and Fountain, Naumburg Bandshell, Bow Bridge and Belvedere Castle.

Greg is joined by special guests along the way — Sara Cedar Miller, historian emerita of the Central Park Conservancy, and Dr. Emma-Guest Consales, president of the Guides Association of New York City.

Listen today on your favorite podcast player.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #centralpark #centralparkconservancy #dakotaapartments #sanremoapartments

Belvedere Castle is one of my favorite spots in Central Park. It was specifically designed to be whimsical! A folly at the top of Vista Rock. Today you can even explore the inside and climb to (almost) the top.

For more on the history of Belvedere Castle, listen to the latest Bowery Boys podcast — The Early Years of Central Park.

#belvederecastle #centralpark #centralparknyc #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast
A lovely afternoon in Central Park at “the Friends fountain”
Beautiful day in Midtown

Next week begins a new Bowery Boys two-part series about the culture and conflicts of one historic lower Manhattan neighborhood. But that story begins here, with the history of one of New York's oldest parks, the 'lungs' of the Lower East Side — Tompkins Square Park.

Here’s what the park looks like today. Tune in to the latest show to hear about its remarkable history. Just released a newly edited and remastered version of this show in your podcast feed. 

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #eastvillage #tompkinssquarepark

In this week’s new Bowery Boys podcast, we celebrate the Ukrainian East Village, settled between Third and Second Avenues at around East 7th Street, right around the time that the beatniks arrived in the 1950s.

Listen to this week’s show to hear the story of Veselka, the historic restaurant which serves ‘Ukrainian soul food’ through good times and bad.

#littleukraine #ukranianvillage #ukranianfood #eastvillage #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

An important cultural landmark from this week’s podcast on the East Village still exists! Albeit nested between modern construction and shaded by trees.

The house is 27 Cooper Square at East 5th Street next to The Standard Hotel. A small plaque marks its importance:

“In the 1960s, this 1845 former rooming house became a laboratory for artistic, literary and political currents. 

Writers LeRoi Jones (later Amiri Baraka) and Hettie Jones, their Yugen magazine and Totem Press, musician Archie Shepp and painter Elizabeth Murray all had homes here. 

The vacant building was transformed into a vital hub of cultural life, attracting leading figures including those from the Beats and the world of jazz.”

#eastvillage #blackartsmovement #boweryboys #blackhistory #jazzhistory

Charging Bull is one of New York City’s top attractions probably because it’s cheap, accessible and weird. There was a line of about 50 people just waiting to take a picture of the bull’s BACKSIDE and testicular region.

Nearby were several souvenir stands selling little bulls. 

#chargingbull #batterypark #lowermanhattan #tourism #nyc #newyorkcity

East Village at night.

#eastvillage #eastvillagenyc #nightphotography #astorplace #nyc #newyorkcitylife

Images of Alphabet City/Loisaida on a sunny afternoon.

#loisaida #alphabetcity #alphabetcitynyc #eastvillage #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #bringartback

At the unveiling of Beastie Boys Square at Ludlow and Rivington.

#beastieboyssquare #beastieboys #boweryboys

The latest episode of the Bowery Boys was recorded on the streets of East Village! Krikor Daglian of True Tales of NYC joined me to tell the story of the East Village of the 1980s and 90s. 

Listen today — especially if you’re nostalgic for the old East Village or just a big fan of the musical Rent.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #truetalesofnyc #eastvillage #eastvillagenyc

The Museum of Reclaimed Urban Space is a most unusual — but very informative — museum on Avenue C, putting a spotlight on activists’ efforts to improve the neighborhood and bring sustainable living to the city. 

The building is located in an actual squat (and former punk music venue) and contains various artifacts from the neighborhood’s recent history including items from the Tompkins Square Riot of 1988.

Hear an interview with Bill Di Paola, founder of the museum, in this week’s podcast.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #eastvillage #alphabetcity #loisaida #museumofreclaimedurbanspace #truetalesnyc

Hurray for Ray’s! We capped off our tour of the East Village with a visit to Ray’s Candy Store, a delectable institution at the southwest corner of Tompkins Square Park since 1974 (and actually traces back to other candy stores from the early 20th century).

Tune in to our latest podcast to hear Ray’s biography and his secret to longevity! 

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #rayscandystore #eastvillage #eastvillagenyc #candy #reesespeanutbuttercups

Inside the fabulous new art space Powerhouse Arts, inside the former “Batcave” next to the Gowanus Canal.

#powerhousearts #gowanus #gowanuscanal #wow #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

The Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site celebrates its 100th anniversary this month. How can that be? (TD was born in 1858.) The house on East 20th Street, operated by the National Park Service, is actually a faithful replica of Roosevelt’s first home, rebuilt a few years after his death in 1919.

It’s a great place to learn about Roosevelt’s life and to get a glimpse of mid 19th century living. Plus it plays a big role in this week’s new Bowery Boys podcast — Theodore Roosevelt’s Wild Kingdom with special guest Ken Burns!

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #theodoreroosevelt #theodorerooseveltbirthplace #nyc #kenburns

A clip from this week’s new Bowery Boys podcast featuring special guest Ken Burns, speaking about his latest film The American Buffalo.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #kenburns #theamericanbuffalo #nyc #bronxzoo

This week’s podcast Theodore Roosevelt’s Wild Kingdom features the origin story of the teddy bear, a regular feature of every childhood nursery that traces back to a 1902 Washington Post editorial cartoon.

It was the cartoon which inspired toy makers like Brooklyn’s Morris and Rose Michtom to create and sell the first ‘Teddy’s Bears’.

Roosevelt’s relationship with the natural world is explored in this week’s podcast, featuring non-fiction film legend Ken Burns!

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #teddyroosevelt #theodoreroosevelt #teddybear #teddybear🐻 #toyhistory

Friday’s flood made for a soggy greeting for the tourists coming off the Queen Mary 2 at the Brooklyn Cruise Terminal.

#queenmary2 #redhookbrooklyn #floodfriday #flooding #brooklyn

One of the more hypnotic recent additions to the American Museum of Natural History is its new hall for gems and minerals. This wall was SO transfixing. Zone out and explore the new sections of the museum (including the recently opened Gilder Center).

#amnh #americanmuseumofnaturalhistory #minerals #boweryboys #boweryboysnyc

A lovely day to visit the American Museum of Natural History don’t you think? Come admire the architecture of the new Richard Gilder Center for Science, Education, and Innovation. 

And stay to check out a couple artifacts mentioned in this week’s Teddy Roosevelt show, including the seal skull which ignited his passion for natural history and a white owl he mounted in taxidermy as a boy.

Find out more on the origins of the AMNH is our latest podcast Theodore Roosevelt’s Wild Kingdom.

#americanmuseumofnaturalhistory #amnh #theidoreroosevelt #upperwestside #upperwestsidenyc #taxidermy

location.city_name: {"id":"2118146924864864","has_public_page":true,"name":"Original Bass Pro, Aquarium, and Museum, Springfield MO. Original Bass Pro","slug":"original-bass-pro-aquarium-and-museum-springfield-mo-original-bass-pro"}

social_posts.post_text:
You may be wondering — where in New York City is the Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Room? It’s not in NYC. It’s actually in the Ozarks!

It’s located within the Bass Pro Shops Outdoor World in Springfield, Missouri, a part of the larger NRA National Sporting Arms Museum. 

I paid a visit to the museum recently to check out the Roosevelt room. Yes this is an actual gun museum and this room devoted to Roosevelt is tucked in the back, celebrating his role as a hunter-naturalist. The room is lightly filled with taxidermy — including a mannequin of Roosevelt himself — compared to the thousands of other examples located throughout this cavernous emporium for sporting goods. 

For more on Teddy Roosevelt’s relationship with the natural world, listen to this week’s new Bowery Boys podcast.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #theodoreroosevelt #teddyroosevelt #bassproshop #bassproworld #taxidermy #gunsofinstagram

Also stopped by the site of last year’s ghost story show — the Old Dutch Church in Kingston. And I even found the mural that depicts the goblin of Dunderberg Mountain.

And I can’t stop in Kingston without paying a visit to the town’s two great bookstores — Rough Draft and Half Moon Books. Picked up David Grann’s The Wager while at Rough Draft….

From this week’s new episode Ghost Stories by Gaslight. Now available! And visit our website for images related to these stories.

social_posts.post_text:
So we don’t know if you’ve heard, but New York City is an expensive place to live these days. So we thought it might be time to revisit the tale of the city’s most famous district of luxury — Fifth Avenue. 

For about a hundred years, this avenue was mostly residential— but residences of the most extravagant kind.

At the heart of New York’s Gilded Age — the late 19th-century era of unprecedented American wealth and excess — were families with the names Astor, Waldorf, Schermerhorn, and Vanderbilt, alongside power players like A.T. Stewart, Jay Gouldand William “Boss” Tweed.

They would all make their homes — and in the case of the Vanderbilts, their great many homes — on Manhattan’s Fifth Avenue.

Why was the avenue considered ‘the spine of New York’? And how did Midtown Manhattan go from farmland to Cartier? Listen today on your favorite podcast player:

#gildedage #gildedagemansions #gildedagehbo #gildedagenewyork #gildedagearchitecture #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #fifthavenue
Friday night bar hopping after our second @joespub show. Couldn’t resist… Thanks for the photo @kylesoutthere

We might call this 1834 mansion rather modest in today’s terms, but it ignited one of New York’s most luxurious trends. This home of Henry Brevoort was once located at Fifth Avenue and 9th Street, built upon farmland the Brevoorts owned north of the newly developed Washington Square and was one of the first mansions built upon the newly carved avenue. The home was a center of New York high society decades before anybody knew what a ‘gilded age’ was.

It was demolished in 1925 and replaced with an apartment building. If you’ve eaten at the lovely restaurant Claudette, you’ve been on the spot of this mansion!

For more information, listen to the latest Bowery Boys podcast The Gilded Age Mansions of Fifth Avenue.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #fifthavenue #washingtonsquarepark #claudette #nyc #newyorkcity

Two live shows at Joe’s Pub down, two to go! Taking a break at the historic Algonquin Hotel — which just so happens to be featured in one of our ghost stories from the live show.

On top of having a couple of their fabulous Round Table themed cocktails, we also met the Algonquin’s famous cat Hamlet.

The lobby has recently been renovated but it still retains a respect for the hotel’s history. And even the hallways are decorated with New Yorker magazines in honor of the hotel’s Jazz Age glories.

Interested in seeing our live show at Joe’s Pub? There may be a few seats left (check with their website) and it will be streaming on Joe’s Pub’s YouTube page on Halloween.

#algonquinhotel #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #beautifulhotels #cocktailsofinstagram

The second season of HBO’s The Gilded Age begins tonight! And after the show you can hear Bowery Boys co-host Tom Meyers on the second season of the Official Gilded Age Podcast which goes live with new episodes one hour after broadcast.

#thegildedage #boweryboys

The rain’s not gonna stop the Red Hook Barnacle Parade, celebrating the neighborhood’s continued resilience since Hurricane Sandy 11 years ago.

#redhookbrooklyn #redhookbarnacleparade #barnacleparade #nyc #paradesofinstagram #redhook

The William A Clark mansion at East 77th Street and Fifth Avenue is an example of ‘too much, too late’. The absurdly large mansion, finished in 1911 at outlandish expense, contained 121 rooms including 31 baths. 

Of course there were hundreds of extravagant mansions on Fifth Avenue at this time. But this one was just TOO extravagant. By this time the wealthy were moving into luxury apartments and building mansions elsewhere (most notably the north shore of Long Island).

By the 1920s the press had dubbed it Clark’s Folly and even published mocking verse — “the brokers scorn his mansion, the Met refused his art; If he could hear Philistines jeer, ‘twould break the old man’s heart”

Few lamented its passing when it was demolished in 1927 and replaced with an apartment building designed by Warren and Wetmore (of Grand Central fame). 

For more information, listen to our latest show The Gilded Age Mansions of Fifth Avenue.

#thegildedage #gildedage #nyc #newyorkcity #fifthavenue #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

Halloween is here! And we’ve got all the ghost stories you need to set the mood. Our complete list of Ghost Stories of Old New York episodes can be found on the website. Dozens of tales from 400 years of history and folklore. And they are also available on Spotify as a complete playlist to perfectly set a spooky mood!

#ghoststories #ghosts #halloween #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

social_posts.post_text:
This week The Gilded Gentleman podcast revisits one of America’s most famous opening nights and the fabulous drama which ensued — on stage and off.

The original Metropolitan Opera House — nicknamed the Yellow Brick Brewery for its bulky exterior design — was built by the families representing New York’s nouveau riche who felt slighted by Old New York’s upper class.

While it was technically Gounod’s opera Faust which played from the stage, most of the spectacle was actually in the audience — and up in the regal boxes, called the ‘golden horseshoe’ for its extravagant roster of social-climbing elite.

Listen to the Gilded Gentleman podcast today for all the juicy details.

#thegildedage #thegildedgentleman #boweryboys #metropolitanopera #metopera #operahouse #opera #nyc #newyorkcity
The Hotel Pennsylvania is gone and in its place, an empty space soon to be filled with something glass covered.

NEW from The Gilded Gentleman podcast — some overlooked history of the 19th century, the story of black life and social class in New York City.

Dr. Carla Peterson, author of Black Gotham: Family History of African Americans in Nineteenth-Century New York City, joins Carl to share her research and perspective on the growth and development of the prosperous black professional class throughout the nineteenth century up to the Gilded Age.

And believe it or not, a few characters from the HBO series “The Gilded Age” were designed with Black Gotham in mind. In particular, the father of Peggy Scott (played by Denée Benton) was based on Peterson’s own ancestral family. 

Listen today on your favorite podcast player.

#gildedage #gildedgentleman #thegildedgentlemanpodcast #thegildedagehbo #boweryboys #blackhistory #newyorkcity

Why did Hollywood movie star Greta Garbo walk the streets of New York City every day for over forty years — under the increasing scrutiny of the press? A tale of glamour, independence, and melancholy in this week’s episode of the Bowery Boys podcast.

Visit the website for further images, a list of resources and credits to the images here.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #classichollywood #oldhollywood #newyorkcity #nyc #gretagarbo #nycwanderings

Keeping with the theme of old movie stars, I visited the International Center of Photography on the Lower East Side to visit the exhibition of hundreds of Marlene Dietrich photographs, many appropriately displayed in the third floor catwalk gallery.

#internationalcenterofphotography #icp #marlenedietrich #lowereastside #photography
Red Hook inlet. It’s so beautiful around the IKEA which is always a weird thing to say.

The Academy of Music, once located at 14th Street and Irving Place, reigned over the high arts (and the wealthy elite) for over thirty years — from its opening in 1854 to the cancellation of its opera season in the mid 1880s due to competition from the Metropolitan Opera.

Learn about this fascinating relic from New York’s past on the Bowery Boys website.

#thegildedage #boweryboys #operahouse #metopera #irvingplace

On this date sixty years ago — November 18, 1963 — Hollywood icon Greta Garbo wrote a letter to Jackie Kennedy, thanking her for a dinner party at the White House five days earlier. After the party, JFK gave Garbo a strange gift — a scrimshaw (or whale’s tooth). Four days after Garbo sent her letter, John F Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas, Texas. The story is featured on this week’s podcast on Garbo’s life in New York City.

#jfk #gretagarbo #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #jackiekennedy #whitehouse

On the new episode of the Bowery Boys podcast, Tom and Greg resurrect a forgotten New York holiday — marking the moment on November 25, 1783 that the British left for good. 

Show goes live on Wednesday, November 22. Listen during your Thanksgiving holiday and bring some colonial flavor to your feasts.

#evacuationday #revolutionarywar #boweryboys #british #georgewashington #nyc #nychistory #newyorkcity #frauncestavern
A happy accident that I walked by to catch this. This tree lighting always makes me smile because it’s modest and beloved and also has a bunch of weird performance-art angels.

For decades New Yorkers celebrated Evacuation Day every November 25, a holiday marking the 1783 departure of British forces from a city they had occupied for several years.

Of course Americans may know late November for another historically themed holiday – Thanksgiving, a New England-oriented celebration that eventually took the place of Evacuation Day on the American calendar. But we are here to tell you listener – you should celebrate both!

Greg and Tom tell the thrilling story of the British’s final years in their former colonies, now in victory known as the United States, and their final moments within New York City, their last remaining haven.

Listen today on your favorite podcast player!

#evacuationday #evacuationdayplaza #newyorkcity #revolutionarywar #americanrevolution #nyc #thanksgiving

This year combine your Thanksgiving celebration with the regional tradition known as Evacuation Day, the moment when the British finally left New York after several agonizing years of war and occupation.

Listen to the new Bowery Boys podcast for more details. And more videos to come about how to mark the ‘great British send off’ in desserts.

#evacuationday #revolutionarywar #americanrevolution #nyc #newyorkcity #baking #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

The British finally left their former colonies (now the United States) 240 years ago today, officially exiting the city of New York at noon. This departure, known as Evacuation Day, was the final moment of the Revolutionary War. 

But I like to call it the Great British Send-Off and I celebrated by baking Loyalist-themed cupcakes. Little goodies to give the soldiers as they left New York for good. Bon voyage!

Cupcakes made with red velvet and French Vanilla cake. Greased flagpole made with rock candy. Frosting by Dolly Parton. 

#evacuationday #nyc #newyorkcity #revolutionarywar #greatbritishbakeoff #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #british #americanrevolution #boweryboyspodcast

Wandering around midtown Manhattan during the holidays can be an assault on the senses.

#christmas #christmastime #christmasdecorations #nyc #newyorkcity #fifthavenue #horses #horsesofinstagram

This week we’re dropping an ultimate Christmas podcast into our feed — Christmas in Old New York — featuring the Gilded Gentleman Carl Raymond, king of Christmas history Jeff Dobbins and actor John Kevin Jones who is again performing to sold out audiences with his version of Charles Dickens and A Christmas Carol.

During the show you’ll hear about the origin of department store display windows so I couldn’t resist visiting the displays this year at Bergdorf Goodman and Macy’s.

Macy’s might be where many retail Christmas traditions began but I preferred the glamorous displays at BG. Seen any cool holiday windows this year?

#christmas #christmaswindows #boweryboys #nyc

The crazy thing about the Saks Fifth Avenue holiday display (by Christian Dior) is that people turned their back on the Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree as though it were a common shrub.

#christmas #christmasdecor #saksfifthavenue #saks #christiandior #astrology #rockefellercenter #xmas #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

Photos from my epic stroll through Midtown Manhattan a couple nights ago, soaking in the bright holiday decor. Yes there were millions of people everywhere but it was worth it. Especially if you grab a hot chocolate (or something stronger) in Bryant Park.

#christmas #christmasdecor #bryantpark #parkavenue #fifthavenue #boweryboys #grandcentral #grandcentralterminal #cartier #christmaslights

The windows at Bloomingdale’s this year aren’t exactly I’m a holiday mode but there is lots of candy.

#bloomingdales #wonka #wonkamovie #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #christmas #christmasdecor #christmaswindows #xmas #nyc #departmentstore

Well this was a festively urban thing to participate in — Christmas carols on Park Avenue! At the beautiful St. Bartholomew’s. Pretty nice weather but would have been better with a little snow.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #stbartholomew #parkavenue #christmascarols #nyc #newyorkcity #churchesofinstagram

In the new Bowery Boys podcast, visit the most fashionable church in mid 19th century New York City, a destination for the most sensational weddings and funerals of the Gilded Age.

#gracechurch #thegildedage #gildedage #gildedagehbo #churchesofinstagram #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

We’re live — at Grace Church! In our new episode on the 19th century landmark house of worship, we’re joined by vicar Harry Krauss, a historian of Grace Church who has also been associated with Saint Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue.

In this episode we look at Grace as the intersection of Gilded Age wealth and religion. Today you can still find the names of Old New York families on the pews they once rented out (a practice discontinued in the 1960s).

Listen to the show today on your favorite podcast player.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #gracechurch #episcopalchurch #gildedage  #churchesofinstagram

The Holiday Train Show at the New York Botanical Garden is not only a great place to celebrate trains but also New York City history.  Trains weave past over 200 New York City and state landmarks — past and present — all made of plant materials by Applied Imagination.

From Gilded Age mansions to legendary Coney Island theme parks! All presented in a fairytale landscape within Haupt Conservatory. 

#newyorkbotanicalgarden #christmasdecor #appliedimagination #bronxbotanicalgarden #bronx #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

New York Botanical Garden during the holidays is always a pleasure. 

#christmasdecor #christmastrains #newyorkbotanicalgarden #nybg #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #nyc #newyorkcity #nychistory

The gravesite of Leonard Bernstein and Felicia Montealegre sits on the highest elevation in the borough of Brooklyn, near a Revolutionary War monument in Green-Wood Cemetery.

When he died in 1990, Bernstein was buried with a baton, a copy of Alice in Wonderland and a copy of the score from Mahler’s Fifth Symphony.

More information in our new podcast Leonard Bernstein’s New York, New York, available starting Thursday on your favorite podcast player.

#greenwoodcemetery #leonardbernstein #cemeteriesofinstagram #brooklyn #nyc #boweryboyspodcast #boweryboys #musichistory101 #musichistorypodcast

You can pay your respects to Leonard Bernstein and his wife Felicia Montealegre at a rather magical spot in one of America’s most historic cemeteries.

Our new podcast Leonard Bernstein’s New York, New York looks at the city’s influence upon his work and life. 

#maestro #maestrofilm #leonardbernstein #greenwoodcemetery #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

Here are the original posters (and one Playbill) for all six Broadway productions that Leonard Bernstein was involved in. We discuss four of these in our new podcast on Leonard Bernstein’s New York.

His Peter Pan (1950) predated the more famous version from 1954. It was actually a hit! But its legacy has faded due to the more enduring version which starred Mary Martin and later Sandy Duncan. (Bernstein’s friends Comden and Green did add some lyrics.)

His show 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, however, was a massive flop when it opened on 1976.

#broadwaymusicals #leonardbernstein #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

What did you think of the new film Maestro starring Bradley Cooper as Leonard Bernstein? Well if you liked it — or perhaps even more so if you didn’t — check out our latest podcast Leonard Bernstein’s New York, New York which looks at his life from the perspective of the city which made his career.

Featuring:
— The story of his infamous ‘radical chic’ party on Park Avenue
— The legendary Greenwich Village venue where he performed with friends Betty Comden and Adolph Green
— The night he shocked the old Metropolitan Opera House
— His first major New York orchestra before the Philharmonic … thanks to Mayor Fiorello La Guardia
— His life at the Dakota Apartments

Listen today on your favorite podcast player! And visit the website for a Bernstein-flavored Spotify playlist

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #maestrofilm #leonardbernstein #newmovies #nyphilharmonic

Leonard Bernstein is closely associated with Lincoln Center, the longtime home of the New York Philharmonic, but in this week’s latest podcast Leonard Bernstein’s New York, New York, we actually trace the course of his career through several city landmarks. 

The ones pictured here include:

1. Village Vanguard in Greenwich Village (178 7th Ave S) — where Bernstein performed with Comden and Green. (photo of Pharoah Sanders, John Coltrane, Alice Coltrane, Jimmy Garrison and Rashied Ali from 1966)
2. Adelphi Theater (152 West 54th Street) — where On The Town premiered
3. New York City Center (131 West 55th Street) — where Bernstein conducted the New York City Symphony Orchestra
4. The ‘old’ Metropolitan Opera House (1411 Broadway) — where Fancy Free debuted
5. Winter Garden Theater (1634 Broadway) — where West Side Story premiered
6. Osbourne Apartments (205 West 57th Street) — where Bernstein lived during the 1950s
7. Carnegie Hall (881 Seventh Avenue) — where Bernstein first conducted the New York Philharmonic
8. The penthouse at 895 Park Avenue — where Lenny and Felicia had their infamous ‘radical chic’ party
9. The Dakota Apartments (1 West 72nd Street) — where the Bernsteins lived after the 1960s and where Bernstein died in 1990
10. Greenwood Cemetery — where Lenny and Felicia are buried

For more information, listen to our latest episode today!

#boweryboys #leonardbernstein #maestrofilm #maestro #boweryboyspodcast #Newyorkcity #nyc #carnegiehall #Villagevanguard #broadwayhistory #greenwoodcemetery

Thank you for listening to the Bowery Boys podcast in 2023! This year we explored the origins of important New York landmarks (Grace Church, the Brooklyn Bridge and the Brooklyn Navy Yard), forgotten traditions (Miss Subways), major changes to everyday life (gaslight, automobile parking), important American stories (the sinking of the Titanic, the end of the Revolutionary War) and a two-part look at the ‘creation’ and evolution of the East Village. 

Here are some behind the scenes images of our podcast journey in 2023. Happy new year!

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #boweryboysnyc #podcastlife #podcasting #newyorkcity #nyc

New York City movie of 2023: Past Lives

Runners-Up: A Thousand and One, You Hurt My Feelings (will you ever be able to go into Paragon Sporting Goods without thinking of JLD looking horrified?), Across the Spider-Verse, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem

Fun New York Movie Moments: Maestro, John Wick 4, Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny

What was your favorite New York moment on film or television this year?

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #pastlives #nyc #newyorkcity

Why is the bridge linking Brooklyn and Queens over Newtown Creek named for Polish hero Tadeusz Kosciuszko? That’s the subject of this week’s Bowery Boys podcast. 

The newest bridge (or actually, bridges) opened in 2017 and 2019 and are a delight to walk over with amazing views of the  skyline and Calvary Cemetery. Even Newtown Creek looks good from here.

Listen to the latest episode today and plan a walk or a bike ride over the bridge sometime soon.

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #kosciuszko #kosciuszkobridge #bqe #newtowncreek #calvarycemeteryqueens #bridgesofinstagram #tadeuszkościuszko

In the early 19th century, Newtown Creek was crossed by the Penny Bridge, named for its toll fare. When Calvary Cemetery was consecrated in the 1840s, the bridge became the site of hundreds of funeral processions from the Kings County side. 

This plaque marks the spot of where the Penny Bridge would have been crossed. However the site is a bit of a mess today.

But it does make a pretty good place to view the Kosciuszko Bridge (named for the war hero Tadeusz Kościuszko) on the Brooklyn side. My recommendation however is to take in the bridge from the Queens side instead. 
 
Listen to the newest Bowery Boys podcast to hear more about the history of Newtown Creek and the bridges which went over it.

#kosciuszkobridge #brooklyn #bridgesofinstagram #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast

Kosciuszko Plaza marks the spot on the Brooklyn side where pedestrians and bike riders can cross over the Kosciuszko Bridge. The new bust of Kosciuszko was unveiled in 2021.

A couple other interesting points:
— the plaza actually leads to spaces named Under The K Bridge Park which skateboarders should especially enjoy
— features a spectacular mural by @jamiehef 
— the building the mural is placed upon appears to be a store that only sells umbrellas?

Listen to the new Bowery Boys podcast on Kosciuszko — the man and the bridge — available today!

#boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #kosciuszko #kosciuszkobridge #umbrellas #streetart

Edith Wharton’s classic The Age of Innocence has managed to find a new generation of readers in the 21st century. While set in Old New York, its themes of social constraints and unrequited love have timeless appeal. 

Listen to the blockbuster new episode of The Gilded Gentleman podcast, kicking off his third season, to hear the story of its creation, featuring a special guest — author and professor Emily Orlando. Find the Gilded Gentleman wherever you listen to podcasts or head to the Bowery Boys website.

#ageofinnocence #edithwharton #gildedage #gildedgentleman #thegildedgentlemanpodcast #boweryboys #boweryboyspodcast #oldnewyork

If you’re a film buff and a lover of Brooklyn, you must check out the Spike Lee exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum. It’s a mixture of movie memorabilia, rare items from Lee’s collections and objects that are inspired by some of Lee’s greatest movies. It’s a perfectly warm and bright escape from the winter weather! The show run another month through Feb 11.
